A Minimal Book Example Chapter 1 Prerequisites

A Minimal Book Example Yihui Xie 2020-03-31 Chapter 1 Prerequisites This is a sample book written in Markdown. You can use anything that Pandoc’s Markdown supports, e.g., a math equation \(a^2 + b^2 = c^2\). The bookdown package can be installed from CRAN or Github: install.packages("bookdown") # or the development version # devtools::install_github("rstudio/bookdown") Remember each Rmd file contains one and only one chapter, and a chapter is defined by the first-level heading #. To compile this example to PDF, you need XeLaTeX. You are recommended to install TinyTeX (which includes XeLaTeX): https://yihui.org/tinytex/.

Chapter 2 Introduction You can label chapter and section titles using {#label} after them, e.g., we can reference Chapter 2. If you do not manually label them, there will be automatic labels anyway, e.g., Chapter 4. Figures and tables with captions will be placed in figure and table environments, respectively. par(mar = c(4, 4, .1, .1)) plot(pressure, type = 'b', pch = 19) Figure 2.1: Here is a nice figure! Reference a figure by its code chunk label with the fig: prefix, e.g., see Figure 2.1. Similarly, you can reference tables generated from knitr::kable(), e.g., see Table 2.1. knitr::kable( head(iris, 20), caption = 'Here is a nice table!', booktabs = TRUE ) Table 2.1: Here is a nice table! Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa 5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4 setosa 4.6 3.4 1.4 0.3 setosa 5.0 3.4 1.5 0.2 setosa 4.4 2.9 1.4 0.2 setosa 4.9 3.1 1.5 0.1 setosa 5.4 3.7 1.5 0.2 setosa 4.8 3.4 1.6 0.2 setosa 4.8 3.0 1.4 0.1 setosa 4.3 3.0 1.1 0.1 setosa 5.8 4.0 1.2 0.2 setosa 5.7 4.4 1.5 0.4 setosa 5.4 3.9 1.3 0.4 setosa 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.3 setosa 5.7 3.8 1.7 0.3 setosa 5.1 3.8 1.5 0.3 setosa You can write citations, too. For example, we are using the bookdown package (Xie 2020) in this sample book, which was built on top of R Markdown and knitr (Xie 2015). References
Chapter 3 Git Basics 3.1 Initializig a Repository in an Existing Directory 3.2 Cloning an existing git project

Chapter 3 Git Basics There are two ways for obtaining a Git repository: - Transform an existing local directory without version control into a Git repositor - Clone an existing Git repositery from somewhere else 3.1 Initializig a Repository in an Existing Directory First, you have to go to the project directory # work directory initial_repo = "D:/git_test/Git_Book/" setwd(initial_repo) # Repository directory name dir_name = "MyRepo" new_repo = paste(initial_repo,"MyRepo", sep = "/") # verify if the repo file exist and remove it if it exists if(dir.exists("D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo") == TRUE){ unlink("D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo", recursive = TRUE) } # we create a project directory dir.create("MyRepo") ## Warning in dir.create("MyRepo"): 'MyRepo' existe déjà # Then we go to that projetc directory setwd(new_repo) shell("dir") # initialize a git repository shell("git init") This creates a new subdirectory named .git that contains all necessary repository files (a git repository skeleton). Now we can start version-conrolling files and do initial commits. setwd(new_repo) # First we have to specify our identity shell('git config --global user.name "Saif Shabou"') shell('git config --global user.email "saif.shabou@gmail.com"') print(getwd()) ## [1] "D:/git_test/Git_Book/MyRepo" # then we create a new file and commit this action nb = sample(1:1000, 1, replace=TRUE) filename = paste("file_",nb,".csv", sep = "") file.create(filename) ## [1] TRUE cmd_add = paste("git add", filename, sep = " ") shell(cmd_add) shell('git commit -m "adding new file"', intern = TRUE) ## [1] "[master (root-commit) ebb8719] adding new file" ## [2] " 1 file changed, 0 insertions(+), 0 deletions(-)" ## [3] " create mode 100644 file_559.csv" 3.2 Cloning an existing git project shell("git clone https://github.com/S-AI-F/Remote-sensing-image-analysis MyClone", intern = TRUE) ## Warning in system(cmd, intern = intern, wait = wait | intern, ## show.output.on.console = wait, : l'exécution de la commande 'C: ## \WINDOWS\system32\cmd.exe /c git clone https://github.com/S-AI-F/Remote-sensing- ## image-analysis MyClone' renvoie un statut 128 ## character(0) ## attr(,"status") ## [1] 128
